title: Smoke Inhalation
summary: Emergency care for smoke inhalation and airway burns from fires, which can be life-threatening even without visible burns.

steps.title: Move to Fresh Air Immediately
steps.description: Get the person away from smoke and fumes to fresh air immediately. Do not put yourself at risk - let firefighters rescue people from burning buildings. Call 911 immediately for all smoke inhalation cases.

steps.title: Check Breathing and Consciousness
steps.description: Check if the person is conscious and breathing normally. Look for signs of respiratory distress: coughing, wheezing, difficulty breathing, or hoarse voice. If unconscious or not breathing, begin CPR.

steps.title: Look for Warning Signs
steps.description: Check for singed nasal hairs, soot around nose or mouth, burns on face, or coughing up black sputum. These indicate airway burns. Listen for hoarse voice or stridor (high-pitched breathing sound).

steps.title: Position for Easier Breathing
steps.description: If conscious, help the person sit upright or in a position that makes breathing easier. Loosen any tight clothing around the neck and chest. Do not lay them flat unless performing CPR.

steps.title: Give Oxygen if Available
steps.description: If trained and oxygen is available, administer 100% oxygen. Carbon monoxide poisoning is a major concern with smoke inhalation. Continue oxygen until emergency services arrive.

steps.title: Monitor Continuously
steps.description: Watch breathing closely - airways can swell shut hours after exposure. Monitor for confusion, headache, or cherry-red skin color (signs of carbon monoxide poisoning). Keep the person calm and still.

warnings: Airway swelling can occur hours after smoke exposure
Carbon monoxide poisoning may not show immediate symptoms
Never re-enter a burning building to rescue someone
Smoke inhalation can be fatal even without visible burns
whenToSeekHelp: All cases of smoke inhalation require immediate medical evaluation
Any difficulty breathing or change in voice
Persistent coughing or coughing up dark sputum
Any burns to face or signs of airway involvement
preventionTips: Install smoke detectors on every level of your home
Practice fire escape plans with all family members
Sleep with bedroom doors closed to slow smoke spread
Stay low to the ground when escaping through smoke
Never use grills or generators indoors
